report_title: Industry at a Glance: Ornamental and Architectural Metalwork Manufacturing
executive_summary: Ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers develop architectural metalwork, including fences, handrails, balcony rails, screen doors, window guards and other architectural fittings. Over the past five years, the industry expanded with domestic construction. Favorable economic conditions have encouraged nonresidential and residential construction activity. In particular, low interest rates have facilitated investment as the low cost of borrowing bolstered the potential profitability. Still, these trends were derailed by the economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Also, volatile steel and aluminum prices have hindered industry selling prices, further constraining revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Revenue has inched downward at a CAGR of 0.3% over the past five years. It is expected to total $9.5 billion in 2024 when revenue will jump by an estimated 0.9%. Profit has also declined due to rising wages and volatile inputs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Prices of metals and import penetration influence performance
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The price of metals and import penetration heavily influence the industry's performance. Steel and aluminum represent key inputs in the manufacturing process of ornamental and architectural metalwork products. Although rising metal prices increase purchase costs for manufacturers, they also boost the value of inventory and raise selling prices as increased prices are passed down to the customer. Conversely, low steel prices indicate periods of excess supply, weak demand and devalued inventory. Domestic manufacturers have struggled to secure stable purchasing contracts while contending with intense low-cost import competition from Chinese producers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The value of private nonresidential construction is set to recover. Industry performance depends on demand from commercial construction industries and public infrastructure projects. Fortunately for the industry, commercial construction activity, which includes nonresidential work and utility construction, will continue the recovery set in the prior period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increased tariffs will stimulate domestic expansion
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Increased tariffs will stimulate domestic expansion. Import competition will decrease compared with the prior period based on current steel tariffs remaining in place and a depreciation of the US dollar. This expected decline will prove advantageous for domestic manufacturers as low-cost steel imports, particularly from China, are inhibited by an additional 25.0% tariff.

Trade conditions will improve. The rise in industry revenue can also be moderately attributed to favorable trade conditions over the next five years. Domestic manufacturers will benefit from relatively strong international demand for higher-quality metalwork products. A depreciating US dollar will spur demand and make domestically produced goods more attractive to overseas buyers. Despite a beneficial drop in the US dollar, exports will continue accounting for a minority share of industry revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Residential construction activity will increase slowly
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Residential construction activity will increase slowly due to high interest rates. Interest rates will continue to remain high over the outlook period. Since home building and renovation projects take a relatively short time to complete, the level of activity within the residential building market is highly susceptible to the price of financing.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry fabricate, sell, repair and install ornamental metalwork, including fences, handrails, balcony rails, screen doors and window guards, among other architectural products.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Competitive pricing is key to attracting downstream customers.
Ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers must also be able to deliver a range of high-quality products.

Imported metalwork is highly price-competitive and manufactured in developing countries with low labor costs. Domestic manufacturers respond by focusing on higher quality, but this strains profitability.

The Federal Reserve lowered interest rates to stimulate the declining economy. Residential construction activity boomed during the COVID-19 pandemic, as residential work takes a relatively short time to complete and is highly susceptible to financing prices.

Nonresidential construction has historically taken longer to improve post-recession and follows a lag of one to two years compared to the residential construction market. Commercial work has since recovered but has not yet reached prepandemic levels.
Volatile steel prices harm the industry. Rapid increases in steel prices cannot always be quickly offset by spiking up selling prices, causing industry manufacturers to eat the difference.

The industry is highly fragmented. Ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers operate in regional markets and cater to local projects and demand. Most manufacturers only employ an average of one to four employees. The majority provide installation services as the manufacturing process becomes more automated. Manufacturers must also have a thorough understanding of customer preferences in their particular region in order to grow.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Building construction markets, including nonresidential, commercial and residential building construction, include a variety of ornamental and architectural metalwork products necessary for construction, including fences and gates, elevator guide rails, fire escapes, staircases and other products.

Industrial machinery, transportation equipment and other durable goods manufacturers are key markets for ornamental and architectural metalwork products. These products are often integrated into other finished products, such as complete windows, doors and facades.
Other markets include detention and correctional facilities, which use metal staircases, railings and other ornamental and architectural metalwork.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Residential buildings require architectural metal products, such as fences and gates, elevator guide rails, fire escapes, staircases, etc. When demand from the residential construction sector increases, it positively affects the industry. Multifamily projects, in particular, spur demand for metalwork products, given their tall structures and the sheer quantity of products and materials needed. Declines in the value of residential construction pose a potential threat to the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Countries with low labor costs pose a threat to domestic manufacturers
international_trade_points.trade_description: Foreign-based manufacturers have an advantage over domestic manufacturers through low-cost labor, enabling them to offer lower prices. The countries the US imports from the most are China, Canada, India and Mexico.

In August 2018, the United States imposed a 25.0% tariff on various Chinese import items, including steel products. The tariffs retaliated against China's exploitation of US technology and intellectual property.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The Largest Destination for Industry Exports is Canada, Followed by Mexico
international_trade_points.trade_description: Industry trade with Canada and Mexico benefits from advantageous trade conditions with the United States through the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). This agreement, which replaced NAFTA in 2020, dramatically reduced tariffs on goods flowing among these neighboring countries and boosted total trade activity.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A Depreciating Dollar Will Boost Export Volumes Over the Next Five Years
international_trade_points.trade_description: A decreasing trade-weighted index (TWI), which measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of its major trading partners, will benefit industry exports as domestically produced goods become comparatively less expensive for foreign customers.

business_locations.location_description: Florida is attractive for ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers because of its large residential and commercial construction market. Besides being a popular destination for retirees, Florida also houses many commercial resort developments. Basing operations in the Southeast also gives manufacturers access to the Gulf of Mexico, making it easier to export products to Mexico, which is often one of the most prominent export destinations.

California is the most populous state and home to the largest number of establishments and employees in the manufacturing sector. Its coastal location facilitates imports and exports. Also, California is particularly attractive due to its large consumer markets and strong housing demand. The housing boom in California amid the COVID-19 pandemic significantly boosted the state's share of total establishments.

The Mid-Atlantic region includes densely populated cities in New York and New Jersey, which provide a strong source of demand for residential and commercial construction. Dense urban populations and affluence among homeowners in these states provide an ample market for home improvements. The Mid-Atlantic is also a strategic trade location, facilitating easier access to Canada.

The Great Lakes region is home to a large concentration of downstream manufacturing industries, including iron and steel producers. Being close to key suppliers and buyers is highly efficient. Ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers choose to locate in the region because of its proximity to Canada, the largest export market for the United States.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Clean Water Act (CWA), The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) and The Clean Air Act (CAA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Under the CWA and RCRA, manufacturers are responsible for following appropriate water and solid waste discharge procedures and are subject to specific provisions relating to airborne pollution emissions.

The CAA is designed to protect and enhance the nation's air resources to protect public health and welfare. It limits air pollutants, including carbon monoxide, nitrous oxides, sulfur oxides and other particulate matter.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE CLUSTER RULE AND NOISE CONTROL
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Cluster Rule protects human health and the environment by reducing toxic releases to the air and water. The rule applies to most manufacturers in the United States and is enforced by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

In response to the guidance of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), various levels of regulation were implemented in the United States and overseas, discouraging public gatherings, large events and crowded, unsafe work environments.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The level of industry assistance is low and steady.

factors_decreased_barrier: The capital intensity level is low.
The globalization level is low and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Competitive pricing is key to attracting downstream customers.
Ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers must also be able to deliver a range of high-quality products.

Imported metalwork is highly price-competitive and manufactured in developing countries with low labor costs. Domestic manufacturers respond by focusing on higher quality, but this strains profitability.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers are localized and market specific.
The industry exhibits a low level of fragmentation due to the presence of many small companies.
Smaller manufacturers have increasingly catered to niche markets, reducing their susceptibility to competitively priced imports.
Major companies have been better equipped to absorb fluctuations in steel and aluminum prices, so their market share has remained relatively stable over the past five years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases as a share of revenue have decreased over the past five years. Raw material prices, most notably steel and aluminum, are the largest expense for ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers and have been volatile in recent years.
Profit as a share of revenue has decreased over the past five years. Labor costs have outpaced revenue growth, resulting in a lower profit margin.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: SKILLED LABOR IS HIGHLY IMPORTANT, RESULTING IN HIGH WAGE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages as a share of revenue have increased over the past five years. Although the industry continually incorporates new technology to ease the production of standardized products, it remains labor-intensive.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturing is highly labor-intensive. Manufacturers require skilled workers to operate the machinery and computer software.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE PRICE OF METALS INTRODUCES SIGNIFICANT VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue depends on the price of metals, such as steel and aluminum. Fluctuations in steel prices impact industry selling prices. Steel prices have been highly volatile over the past five years.

volatility_points.volatility_title: DOWNSTREAM CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITY GREATLY INFLUENCES METALWORK DEMAND
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is sensitive to trends in both commercial and residential construction.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: THE INDUSTRY HAS SHIFTED TO AUTOMATING THE MANUFACTURING PROCESS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Computer-aided design (CAD) and computer numerically controlled (CNC) machine tools have enabled metalworkers to reduce the labor intensity of the job, improve input usage and minimize waste.

A specific area where technological change is being carried out is minimizing waste from the production processes. Going green continues to be an effective way to differentiate against low-cost imports.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: In line with the manufacturing sector, companies in this industry face competition from abroad. However, when compared to other industries, this industry faces a relatively low level of import competition.

FAQs.question: Have export opportunities offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Growth in the export market typically supports growth for manufacturers.

FAQs.question: Has your company located in proximity to its key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: There is no central location for industry companies to be located for downstream markets, as companies are typically small regional players. Still, the industry buys steel and other products from producers who are most prevalent in the Great Lakes area.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Steel is a key input for industry companies; as a result, steel prices play a major role in industry revenue and profit. Volatility in the price of steel can affect industry profit.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Companies should look to increase efficiency and decrease wage expense by working with third-party robotic companies that build components to aid in the manufacturing process. While human work is necessary for some operations, robots are growing in sophistication.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, such as [example: RFDI tags, etc.], in its operations?
FAQs.answer: The blockchain will continue to grow in importance to this logistics-heavy industry. Using the blockchain, transparency will increase throughout the supply chain process, which will increase efficiency and decrease the likelihood of error.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Upstream manufacturers, including steel and other metal manufacturing industries, are extremely powerful on the local, state and national level as many millions of Americans work in these fields. Companies should look for industry groups to help advance their business and connections.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Tariffs on foreign-made metalwork products or its key inputs including steel, are expected to boost the domestic industry. Growth in the price of imports rises, shifting demand to domestic producers, which, in turn, will also contribute to companies' ability to raise prices and increase revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects that require capital financing on the horizon?
FAQs.answer: When interest rates are low, companies consider expansion. However, when interest rates rise or are high, this makes projects costlier.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: The price of steel is a key input and its price has major effects on the industry. Recently imposed tariffs on steel will also affect the price of steel.

FAQs.question: What stock control measures does this company use? How do you aim to keep inventory costs to a minimum?
FAQs.answer: The ability of ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers to either negotiate long-term contracts for steel and aluminum or vertically integrate and supply their own inputs provides a key competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: How do you keep abreast of the most up-to-date technological trends? How has automation affected your cost structure?
FAQs.answer: Wages account for a significant portion of this industry's cost structure. Through automation in production, ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers can reduce costs to undercut competitors' prices and maintain higher profit margins.

FAQs.question: Do you have contracts with key repeat customers? How can you promote your company organically, especially by word-of-mouth recommendations?
FAQs.answer: Being able to anticipate consumer demands and fabricate new products as preferences change will keep a company one step ahead of the competition.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index? How have fluctuations in the value of the US dollar affected demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: Growth in the TWI signals a dollar appreciation and industry exports become less competitive in international markets.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating aluminum prices affect your company? How can you capitalize on the fluctuations in price of aluminum?
FAQs.answer: Aluminum is a major input used to manufacture railings, fencing and other architectural and ornamental metal products. Industry input costs move in line with the price of aluminum.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in housing starts? How have fluctuations in housing starts influenced demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: Ornamental and architectural metalwork manufacturers develop architectural metalwork products, which are used in residential homes. Growth in the number of housing starts boost demand for industry products.
